item.title: Our first look at the Steam Machine, Valve‚Äôs ambitious new game console
item.content:encoded:
Valve is about to challenge the Xbox and PlayStation on their home turf. Ten years to the month after Valve‚Äôs original Steam Machines went on sale, the company is announcing‚Ä¶ the Steam Machine.

I flew to Valve‚Äôs headquarters to try the company‚Äôs new PC-based game console, alongside a brand-new Steam Controller and the new Steam Frame gaming headset. It‚Äôs the culmination of Valve‚Äôs hardware and software efforts over the last decade, and it looks a lot like the leaks that have been coming out over the past year.

Here‚Äôs what the new Steam Machine is all about.

Photo by Everything Time Studio / The Verge

The promise

Shipping early 2026 in every region where the Steam Deck is sold today, Valve‚Äôs new living room box is best thought of as a far more powerful, stationary version of the same technology. It‚Äôs a 6-inch cube that runs Windows games, but without Windows at the helm. Like the Steam Deck, it runs Valve‚Äôs Linux-based SteamOS operating system, using a compatibility layer called Proton to make games think they‚Äôre running on Windows and translate their API calls.

If that sounds like a huge compromise, you should know that countless happy Steam Deck users disagree. The Steam Deck has dramatically outsold Windows handhelds through word of mouth alone, because Linux now runs Windows games better than Windows, and because Windows is far from the Steam Deck‚Äôs pick-up-and-play console experience. I‚Äôve heard many lapsed gamers say the Steam Deck brought them back.

But the Steam Machine has two things the Steam Deck does not: raw power, and the promise that you‚Äôll never be waiting around for a game to update. ‚ÄúThe Steam Machine has the ability to keep all your software, your OS, your games, and your cloud saves updated in the background ‚Ä¶ so the games are always ready for you to play,‚Äù says Valve hardware engineer Yazan Aldehayyat.

While the Steam Deck is more powerful than a Nintendo Switch, it‚Äôs nowhere near a PS5. Big-budget games are beginning to leave it behind, and even the Nintendo Switch 2 can provide better 4K-upscaled TV graphics in its docked mode.

The Steam Machine is Valve‚Äôs answer, bringing the Deck experience to your TV with far more powerful guts. Valve says it offers six times the power of a Steam Deck, and it looks like it‚Äôll offer at least PS5-level performance and possibly beat the PS5 Pro.

Photo by Everything Time Studio / The Verge

Two chips for PS5-plus performance

Under the hood, you get not one but two AMD chips along with 16GB of DDR5 RAM: The CPU is a six-core AMD Zen 4 chip with up to 30 watts of headroom and 4.8GHz boost, while the graphics are a semi-custom discrete AMD RDNA 3 ‚ÄúNavi 33‚Äù GPU, with 28 compute units, up to 130-watt TDP, and 8GB of GDDR6 memory. These are unusual components for a gaming PC, but they might work well together!

While the former sounds a lot like the entry-level AMD Ryzen 5 8540U laptop chip, right down to its two big cores and four small ones, there‚Äôs no direct equivalent to that GPU: the closest are AMD‚Äôs Radeon RX 7700 and 7600 mobile parts, which have almost exclusively appeared in external graphics cards (with two notable exceptions) and offer similar or better theoretical performance to the PS5 Pro‚Äôs graphics.

While I didn‚Äôt have time for robust testing at Valve‚Äôs headquarters, my first impressions were promising. On a 4K TV, the demanding Cyberpunk 2077 benchmark averaged a smooth 65fps at medium settings with basic ray tracing turned on, while being upscaled to 4K from a native 1080p output using AMD‚Äôs FSR 3.0. The benchmark never dipped below 58 frames per second, and when I took the controls for a spin in one of the more demanding regions of the game, the lowest I saw was 55fps in a quick firefight. It looked nice and crisp from about 9 feet away.

The prototype didn‚Äôt do nearly as well at native 4K ‚Äî just 24fps average ‚Äî but consoles generally don‚Äôt play the most demanding games at native 4K, either. I also benched with the same 720p settings I use to test every handheld and saw a solid 131fps, though the low resolution looked pretty ugly on a 4K TV!

Photo by Everything Time Studio / The Verge

Compressed steam

How did Valve fit PS5 power into a box around half the size of a PS5 at just 3.8 liters, including an internal power supply so you don‚Äôt need a separate brick? When Valve hands me a peeled-apart Steam Machine to let me peek inside, the answer is: there‚Äôs almost no wasted space within.

Aldehayyat says the team designed the entire Steam Machine around its cooling system ‚Äî starting with a whisper-quiet 120mm PC fan with custom blade geometry. ‚ÄúWe probably have more computational fluid dynamics time on this than an F1 team in a calendar year,‚Äù he jokes. ‚ÄúWe have a lot of wind tunnel time on it as well.‚Äù

1/10

Then, Valve and component partners built a massive finned heatsink just as tall as that fan, with embedded heat pipes ‚Äî and made it pull double duty as the RF shielding between the motherboard and its four dedicated antennas, including two for Wi-Fi 6E, one for Bluetooth, and one just for connecting to its new Steam Controllers. Below the custom motherboard is a custom Chicony power supply that also doubles as RF shielding for the Steam Machine‚Äôs bottom components, including a full-size M.2 2280 SSD bay that also accepts the smaller M.2 2230 drives the Steam Deck uses.

It‚Äôs all sandwiched together into an incredibly dense, weighty package where the main gaps are all dedicated to airflow: the space around the massive heatsink‚Äôs fins, the vents on the bottom, and the multiple vents in front. Aldehayyat says Valve knew it couldn‚Äôt count on a lot of airflow in the living room, so it designed a lot of redundancy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really hard to block every single one of those vents.‚Äù

Plus, those vents on the front are where the Steam Machine‚Äôs swappable magnetic front panel lives. While the basic design is plain black, Valve shows me a wood panel that gives the Steam Machine a Fractal vibe and a Team Fortress 2-themed panel, and I even spot a panel with an embedded e-paper display which reveals that the Steam Machine is codenamed ‚ÄúFremont‚Äù after all.

Photo by Everything Time Studio / The Verge

Expandability

Valve won‚Äôt necessarily sell any of those extra panels, but says it‚Äôll release the CAD files so you can design and 3D print your own. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure someone will make a [Portal] Companion Cube out of this, but we did not,‚Äù Valve engineer Steve Cardinali tells us when we ask. Below the panel, Valve also has a customizable RGB light bar that it plans to turn into a progress indicator for downloads and updates.

And this Steam Machine will finally be (optionally) sold with a gamepad that‚Äôs both familiar and worthy of playing PC games from the couch. The new Steam Controller is no longer a bulbous experiment in precision but now a comfortable, familiar, and powerful twist on a traditional gamepad (read my colleague Jay Peters‚Äô story for more).

Photo by Everything Time Studio / The Verge

The downside of Valve‚Äôs impressive sandwich is that the Steam Machine isn‚Äôt really upgradable beyond the SSD and ‚Äî if you dig deep ‚Äî the 16GB of memory, which does come on standard laptop memory sticks. But the upside is an incredibly tiny game console that can alternatively double as a full desktop PC.

The Steam Machine has twin display outputs (HDMI 2.0, DisplayPort 1.4) so you can hook up two desktop monitors at a time or daisy-chain DisplayPort for a third. Across the front and back are four USB-A ports (two USB 2, two USB 3) for peripherals, with both a 10Gbps USB-C port and Gigabit Ethernet around back.

You should be able to plug in just about anything ‚Äî including Valve‚Äôs new 6GHz dongle that gives the console a direct wireless connection to the Steam Frame headset ‚Äî and you can install Windows if you really want.

Got any burning questions about Valve‚Äôs new hardware?

We‚Äôre holding a subscriber-exclusive AMA today, November 12th, at 3PM ET. Drop your questions here and we‚Äôll do our best to answer them.

If this exact Steam Machine is not your cup of tea, the company hints that other versions might be available through partners in the future. While Valve won‚Äôt repeat history, letting companies go wild and create a ragtag band of various kinds of Steam Box like it did a decade ago, Valve says it‚Äôs willing to let end users try desktop SteamOS on their own PCs ‚Äî and selectively work with companies, like it did with Lenovo, to bring future Steam Machines to market.

But partners probably will want to see how Valve‚Äôs own Steam Machine fares first, designer Pierre-Loup Griffais suggests to me.

Photo by Everything Time Studio / The Verge

The burning question

In the two weeks since I set foot in Valve‚Äôs headquarters, there‚Äôs only been one big question on my mind: What will this cost? Will Valve price it like a console, putting the Steam Machine toe-to-toe with PS5 Pro? Or will it be priced like a PC, making buyers weigh a heftier price against the opportunity to tap the PC‚Äôs wider library of games?

Valve says it hasn‚Äôt finalized pricing yet. But when I explicitly ask if the console will cost more than a PS5 Pro, the answer is: ‚ÄúSteam Machine‚Äôs pricing is comparable to a PC with similar specs.‚Äù When I listen to my interview audio, I find an additional hint from Griffais: ‚ÄúWe intend for it to be positioned closer to the entry level of the PC space, but to be very competitive with a PC you could build yourself from parts.‚Äù

Poking around the web, I find I could probably assemble a computer with this performance for $800, not including labor. But it could easily consume half the room under my TV. A compact system with a similar GPU can cost $1,000 without storage, memory, operating system, or a gamepad.

But hey, everything about buying video games is getting more confusing and expensive these days. If Valve can deliver a pick-up-and-play console that supports decades of inexpensive PC games, I know people who‚Äôll put down PC amounts of money to get it.

item.title: Steam Machines have returned: all the news about Valve‚Äôs new hardware universe
item.content:encoded:
Highlights

  • Valve enters the console wars
  • Our first look at the Steam Machine, Valve‚Äôs ambitious new game console
  • The Steam Frame is a surprising new twist on VR
  • Valve‚Äôs new Steam Controller might be my dream controller

  • Valve thinks Arm has ‚Äòpotential‚Äô for SteamOS handhelds, laptops, and more

    Valve won‚Äôt talk about a Steam Deck 2. It probably wants to keep the attention on its just-announced living room console, comfy new controller, and Arm-based headset instead. But now that the company is preparing to sell an Arm headset, one that can even run Android apps, there‚Äôs an obvious question. Is Arm a one-off experiment for Valve, or might it power future SteamOS hardware?

    Valve software engineer Pierre-Loup Griffais makes it sound like the sky‚Äôs the limit. I don‚Äôt want to oversell what he said ‚Äî he was excited about the potential, not any specific devices, and you‚Äôll see that in more context when we publish the interview later this week.

    Read Article >

  • Valve is welcoming Android games into Steam

    You can think of the just-announced Steam Frame as a wireless VR headset for your PC, or a Steam Deck for your face. But another way to think about it is that Valve is finally entering the mobile realm. The Frame doesn‚Äôt just run Windows games on its Arm-based Qualcomm Snapdragon chip ‚Äî Valve will now support and encourage developers to bring their Android apps to Steam as well.

    It‚Äôll try to make some of them first-class citizens, too, Valve engineer Jeremy Selan tells The Verge. ‚ÄúFrom the user‚Äôs perspective, our preference is that they don‚Äôt even have to think about it, they just have their titles on Steam, they download them and hit play.‚Äù

    Read Article >

  • Valve has no news about Steam Deck 2

    Photo by Vjeran Pavic / The Verge

  • Valve enters the console wars

    Image: Kristen Radtke / The Verge, Valve

    On the 15th floor of an upscale office building in Bellevue, Washington, security guards line the halls. They‚Äôre here to make sure we don‚Äôt stray ‚Äî because I‚Äôm visiting Valve‚Äôs headquarters, a place few journalists ever get to go. The guards help escort me to a tiny demo room, where a pair of Valve engineers show me their pride and joy: a glowing 6-inch cube, barely bigger than a box of Kleenex, that they hope might be the future of video game consoles.

    For a moment, I feel like I‚Äôm watching history repeat itself. Twelve years ago, in a different Valve office half a mile away, the maker of Half-Life and Portal showed me what ultimately became one of the biggest technology flops of the decade, a new gaming system called the Steam Machine. Back then, it also looked like Valve was building the video game console of the future. The company had combined its vibrant Steam storefront with the flexibility of PC hardware ‚Äî a formula that appeared poised to wrest the living room away from Xbox and PlayStation dominance.

    Read Article >

  • Our first look at the Steam Machine, Valve‚Äôs ambitious new game console

  • The Steam Frame is a surprising new twist on VR

    Valve is about to launch a new virtual reality headset, and with it, a comprehensive new approach to what a VR device should be. Most VR headsets I‚Äôve tried have ended up collecting dust after the novelty wore off, and I thought I had sworn off VR for good. But after trying Valve‚Äôs new headset for myself at the company‚Äôs headquarters, I was nearly ready to put down my credit card before I walked out the door.

    The new headset is called the Steam Frame, and it‚Äôs trying to do several things at once. It‚Äôs a standalone VR headset with a smartphone-caliber Arm chip inside that lets you play flat-screen Windows games locally off the onboard storage or a microSD card. But the Frame‚Äôs arguably bigger trick is that it can stream games directly to the headset, bypassing your unreliable home Wi-Fi by using a short-range, high-bandwidth wireless dongle that plugs into your gaming PC. And its new controllers are packed with all the buttons and inputs you need for both flat-screen games and VR games.

    Read Article >

  • Valve‚Äôs new Steam Controller might be my dream controller

    One of the best parts of the Steam Deck is its many different controls, and how you can customize them to let you do whatever you want with every single one of your games. Now, Valve is bringing that same level of flexibility into a new gamepad. I recently got to try it at Valve‚Äôs headquarters, and it feels like the controller I‚Äôve always wanted.

    Today, Valve announced the second-generation Steam Controller. It‚Äôs a Bluetooth controller that works with any device that runs Steam, including Valve‚Äôs new Steam Machine PC and Steam Frame VR headset, and comes with a puck that serves as a low-latency wireless connector and doubles as a charging station. It will launch in early 2026 for a price that‚Äôs yet to be announced, though Valve is aiming to make the price competitive with other controllers with ‚Äúadvanced inputs,‚Äù according to hardware engineer Steve Cardinali.

    Read Article >

  • Here‚Äôs the secret Steam Machine that Valve probably used to test headsets.

    Jon Bringus isn‚Äôt saying how he obtained this unicorn, but it looks completely legit!

    It self-IDs as a ‚ÄúValve Steambox,‚Äù fires up a Steam screen, makes Steam hardware sounds, and natively pairs with Steam Controllers! Intriguing components inside, like a presence-sensing front panel that fires up its iconic ring light. It appears to have a VirtualLink USB-C port, so it probably helped Valve designers test wired VR headsets before that standard failed.

  • Valve‚Äôs master plan for Steam Machines is finally coming into focus

    Photo by Vjeran Pavic / The Verge

  • In case you missed it, the Dreamcast-shaped EmuDeck Machine is dead.

    There were reasons to be skeptical of the turnkey, emulator-centric Steam Machine idea, and reasons to root for it too ‚Äî but in the end, Sedano tells me he only got around 40 orders, and that he needed closer to 100.

    He says he‚Äôs already refunded every backer, and did produce these two cases before shutting the project down:

  • Remember Steam Machines? EmuDeck founder revisits Valve‚Äôs TV console idea

    Valve once dreamt of building Linux-based game consoles called Steam Machines. They flopped ‚Äî but the dream eventually became reality as the handheld Steam Deck instead. Now, a particularly noteworthy Steam Deck enthusiast is reviving the idea of a console-sized Steam Box, one with his own retro gaming twist.

    Rodrigo Sedano is the founder of EmuDeck, a program beloved by the Steam Deck community. It automatically installs, configures, and enhances emulators for Nintendo, Sega, Sony, and other retro consoles so they work beautifully on Valve‚Äôs handheld.

    Read Article >

  • Wait, wait... HDMI and DisplayPort could‚Äôve been a single port THIS WHOLE TIME?

    Every desktop GPU should ship with four of these unholy things.

  • Farewell to the Steam Link, the best wireless HDMI gadget ever made (update: it‚Äôs $2.50)

    Why am I sad that a tiny black puck which streamed games over a Wi-Fi network will soon disappear from shelves around the world? Because too few people experienced the magic that the Steam Link affords.

    Over the past couple years, it seemed like PC gaming juggernaut Valve couldn‚Äôt give away the gadget fast enough, charging as little as $2.50 for the $50 gadget on sale. That‚Äôs probably why the company is quietly discontinuing the device today, though the company will continue support. (Valve says the Steam Link is already selling out around the world, and when it‚Äôs gone, it‚Äôs gone.)

    Read Article >

  • Gaming performance on Valve‚Äôs SteamOS can‚Äôt keep up with Windows

    Valve‚Äôs new console-aping Steam Machines could be hampered by the performance of the company‚Äôs Linux-based SteamOS operating system compared to Windows gaming. An Ars Technica analysis published Friday morning highlighted considerable performance gaps between SteamOS and Windows on a computer running both operating systems, gaps that persisted across both AAA ports and games built on Valve‚Äôs own Source engine. The operating systems performed similarly in benchmark tool Geekbench 3, but tests involving Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor and Metro: Last Light Redux yielded frames per second gaps that ranged from 21 to 58 percent.

    The timing of the analysis isn‚Äôt ideal for Valve. The company‚Äôs first set of Steam Machines and peripherals were officially made available for purchase last week, including machines from Alienware, Zotac, and Cyberpower. If there‚Äôs a sizable gap in performance between SteamOS and Windows, it‚Äôs hard to argue against spending a little bit more on machines with comparable internals that run Windows instead.

    Read Article >

  • Valve‚Äôs first Steam Machines and controller have been officially released

    The first wave of Valve‚Äôs Steam Machine gaming PCs are now on sale. The company just announced the official launch of Steam Machines from a handful of manufacturers, along with the unusual Steam Controller and the Steam Link home streaming box. Right now, Valve is advertising three Steam Machines from Alienware, Zotac, and Cyberpower; they range from $499 to $1,499. The Steam Controller and Steam Link both sell for $49 apiece.

    The Steam Machine concept has been years in the making, and it‚Äôs seen some delays and false starts along the way. The confusion is partly because ‚ÄúSteam Machine‚Äù is more a label for console-like gaming PCs than a discrete product. Along with the controller, Steam Machines are largely defined by Steam OS, a Linux-based operating system that any manufacturer can adopt, whether it‚Äôs making a super-cheap machine or a top-of-the-line gaming powerhouse. Preorders finally opened this summer, with a limited number of customers getting their devices in mid-October before the official release.

    Read Article >

  • Alienware‚Äôs Alpha console will bring Steam to your living room this November

    If you‚Äôve been wanting to get Steam games into your living room ‚Äî and don‚Äôt want to wait for Valve‚Äôs official Steam OS‚Äî Alienware is now ready to take your money. Interested buyers can now pre-order the Alienware Alpha console, which starts at $549. That‚Äôll get you an Intel Core i3 processor, 4GB of RAM, 500GB of storage, and a custom Nvidia-based graphics card with 2GB of dedicated memory. Alienware is also selling a number of other configurations with more memory, hard drive space, and faster processors.

    What‚Äôs most notable about the Alpha, however, is what isn‚Äôt included ‚Äî instead of using Valve‚Äôs Linux-based Steam OS and the Steam controller, the Alpha is essentially a standard Windows 8.1 PC. After Valve announced that it would delay the Steam OS and controller to 2015, Alienware decided to design its own user interface on top of Windows rather than delay its console. The goal of that custom interface is to provide users a way to get right into Steam‚Äôs ‚Äúbig picture‚Äù mode without having to mess around in Windows or use a keyboard and mouse.

    Read Article >

  • Valve delays Steam Machines and controller until 2015

    Valve, the company behind Portal, Half-Life, and digital video game download service Steam, has delayed the launch of its first pieces of hardware, pushing the release window of its Steam Machines and Steam controller from 2014 to 2015. In a post on Steam, Valve‚Äôs Eric Hope suggested the release dates were pushed back to allow the company to work on the controller, after live playtests with wireless prototypes generated a ‚Äúton of useful feedback.‚Äù While Hope said that feedback means Valve will be able to make its Steam controller ‚Äúa lot better,‚Äù it‚Äôs also keeping the team behind the project ‚Äúpretty busy making all those improvements.‚Äù

    Valve‚Äôs Steam controller, first announced in 2013, is the result of more than two years of research and design by the video game company. In its current form, the controller sports two touchpads on its front, in place the analog sticks present on most modern console controllers. Using the touchpads offers players very precise control over their games, but as The Verge reported last November, the experience isn‚Äôt immediately intuitive for people weaned on analog stick or keyboard and mouse control.

    Read Article >

  • Valve shows off updated Steam Controller design

    We knew Valve‚Äôs Steam Controller would be undergoing some changes, and now the company is offering a more detailed look at its revised gamepad. The touchscreen seen on the original model has indeed been scrapped entirely in favor of four separate directional buttons on the left side and four face buttons on the right. They‚Äôre labeled X, Y, A, and B ‚Äî just like Microsoft‚Äôs Xbox controller ‚Äî and Valve‚Äôs buttons also share the same arrangement and color scheme. Similar to the Xbox One, Valve‚Äôs latest iteration of the Steam Controller features a logo that glows white when powered on. That round button is centered between two smaller ones labeled with icons for stop and play.

    ‚ÄúThese analog buttons are offered in addition to the touch pads featured in the original prototypes,‚Äù Valve said in a statement. The design of this latest version seems to have been finalized only recently; Valve says it‚Äôs in the process of assembling demo units that it will bring to the Game Developers Conference in San Francisco next week. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre excited to get some feedback from our customers on these latest changes,‚Äù the company said. That suggests that Valve may not be done tweaking the Steam Controller as it prepares for a huge push in the living room with SteamOS.

    Read Article >

  • Valve posts entirety of Steam Dev Days to YouTube, explaining its console and VR strategy

    Valve is a notoriously private game publisher, and in January it hosted a private event. At Steam Dev Days, the company gathered developers to talk about its strategy for the company‚Äôs Linux-based Steam Machine game consoles, virtual reality headgear, in-game economies, and game development, all with no journalists in attendance. While some news trickled out in the form of tweets, including when we can expect Alienware‚Äôs Steam Machine to arrive and that the Steam Controller is due for another revision, we weren‚Äôt able to get the full picture. Now, however, the entiretry of Steam Dev Days is on YouTube for your viewing pleasure.

    Valve has uploaded video of all the sessions, and you can find PowerPoint and PDF slidedecks at this link. If you want to know what Valve is working on, here‚Äôs your chance to hear it directly from the company.

    Read Article >

  • Steam In-Home Streaming lets you play away from your PC

    With the right hardware setup, you may no longer need to sit in front of your gaming machine. With a PlayStation Vita, you can play PS4 anywhere in your house. With an Nvidia Shield, you can do the same with a Windows gaming PC. But what if you don‚Äôt want to buy a multiple-hundred dollar handheld game system to play Tomb Raider in bed? Valve is building a game streaming solution right into its free Steam game platform, so you can sling games from your beefy desktop PC to laptops as thin as a MacBook Air. Late last week, Valve invited a host of new users into the Steam In-Home Streaming beta, and we made it in. Read on for our first impressions.

    The first, most striking thing about Steam In-Home Streaming is how little setup it requires. You don‚Äôt even need to be in front of both computers to pair them together. As long as both computers are signed into your Steam account and connected to the same network, you‚Äôll automatically have access to any game or program in either computer‚Äôs Steam library. That means you can stream Windows games to a Mac or Linux machine, and Valve is planning to add support for the reverse, too. If you‚Äôve got a copy of a game that works on both operating systems, you can pick whether to stream it or run it locally, or even start installing it on the remote computer. You can even launch some non-Steam apps, like Adobe Photoshop and Media Player Classic, if you add them to Steam. They don‚Äôt properly display their menu bars, though.

    Read Article >

  • Steam Controller ditches the touchscreen for better backwards compatibility

    The Steam Controller is going to change. According to two game developers tweeting from Valve‚Äôs Steam Dev Days developer summit, Valve has decided to remove the controller‚Äôs central touchscreen. While it sounds like the gamepad‚Äôs twin trackpads will remain intact, the touchscreen was deemed redundant and possibly even distracting from games, as Valve wants players looking at the television instead of their hands. That doesn‚Äôt mean there won‚Äôt be customizable controls in the center of the gamepad, though. Players will simply use a feature that Valve‚Äôs calling ‚Äúghost mode.‚Äù

    We saw an early demo of ‚Äúghost mode‚Äù at Valve‚Äôs headquarters a few months ago, and it‚Äôs fairly simple: when you move your thumb on the Steam Controller‚Äôs touchpad, you can see a ghostly image of your thumb on your TV screen as well, and you can press virtual buttons placed there.

    Read Article >

  • Alienware‚Äôs Steam Machine will arrive in September

    Alienware has perhaps the most exciting Steam Machine coming to market, and now we know when it will arrive. According to a tweet from Dave Oshry, a video game marketing exec attending Valve‚Äôs Steam Dev Days developer summit, the company just announced that Alienware‚Äôs Steam Machine will launch in the September timeframe. That‚Äôs quite a ways away.

    While we don‚Äôt know the exact specs of Alienware‚Äôs box, it is quite small at just three inches tall and eight inches on a side, and it aims to compete with next-gen game consoles in both specs and price. We tried a system that Alienware said was representative of the final machine in terms of performance, and its Intel CPU and Nvidia discrete GPU seemed capable of handling current PC games at 1080p. Valve certainly believes in the machine ‚ÄúThis machine is the one that we think is actually going to serve the most customers and make the most Steam users happy,‚Äù Valve designer Greg Coomer told us late last year.

    Read Article >

  • SteamOS now supports Intel and AMD graphics

    Building your own Steam Box just got a heck of a lot easier, because the SteamOS operating system isn‚Äôt limited to Nvidia GPUs anymore. As of the latest SteamOS release, both Intel and AMD graphics are supported. Mind you, SteamOS is still very much in beta, and the Linux video drivers are in a beta state as well, so don‚Äôt expect too much. AMD specifically mentions that there are some screen-tearing issues, and that things can slow down when the SteamOS overlay and games are running simultaneously. Valve engineer John Vert writes that the company is still working with Intel and AMD to fix a number of these issues.

    That‚Äôs good, because a number of Steam Machines intend to ship with AMD and Intel graphics at launch, including the $499 iBuyPower box, the $499 CyberPowerPC computer, and at least two tiny Brix boxes made by Gigabyte.

    Read Article >

  • Valve reportedly about to release a standard interface for virtual reality controllers

    Next week, Valve will release a software development kit that gives developers a standard way to implement controls in VR games, the BBC reports. Valve designer Brian Coomer has apparently said that the kit is ‚Äúdays away‚Äù and will be released at Steam Dev Days, which start on January 15th. There‚Äôs not much more detail given, but the company has already said it plans to reveal a prototype that will show ‚Äúwhat affordable Virtual Reality (VR) hardware will be capable of within a couple of years.‚Äù Valve has previously worked in partnership with Oculus, whose latest VR headset ‚Äî a prototype known as Crystal Cove ‚Äî was announced at CES.

    The controller development kit will reportedly come as part of the larger set of software tools for Steam Machines, about a dozen of which have also been revealed this week. Valve has made itself a link between manufacturers and developers, creating a platform that ensures compatibility across a variety of hardware, and it‚Äôs well-positioned to do the same for virtual reality controllers, which range from simple gamepads to elaborate circular treadmills. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been talking to Oculus pretty extensively... about how we can help them with Steam,‚Äù Valve told us last year.

    Read Article >

  • Valve announces 13 Steam Machine partners, including Alienware

    Valve has been unveiling its SteamOS initiative piece by piece, and at a brief event today it announced an important new detail: which companies will actually be selling Steam Machines. Thirteen partners were announced at the event, including Alienware, Falcon Northwest, and iBuyPower, among other custom PC makers. There‚Äôs no word on precisely when the machines will hit the market, but Valve business manager DJ Powers tells us that its hoping to see some on the shelf in the latter half of 2014.

    As for whether we‚Äôll see hardware from Valve itself, it isn‚Äôt something the company is ruling out ‚Äî though it is staying typically quiet on the subject. But one thing is for sure: the 300 prototypes that Valve sent out in 2013 aren‚Äôt going to be making a further appearance. ‚ÄúThat was an exercise to kind of prove the concept and get them in customers‚Äô hands to get real honest feedback,‚Äù says Powers. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have further plans to manufacture more of those boxes and run a bigger beta or sell them.‚Äù

    Read Article >

More Stories

item.title: Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines 2's latest patch offers up fixes, as a roadmap promises more improvements
item.content:encoded:
You can quit without fear now too

Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines 2 is, in Dominic's own words, "merely okay." I haven't played it myself, so I can't comment there, the general consensus seems to be in agreement on that point however. The Chinese Room are working on turning that around at least! Today they released a new patch for the RPG, containing a bunch of fixes, and offered up a small roadmap of improvements and DLC to come.

Let's start with what this patch, patch 1.0.4, offers up. The big one is that previously, if you would exit to the main menu or quit the game, the game wouldn't save, resulting in a lost of lost hours of playtime. Now, the game does autosave, updating progress for collectables, blood resonance, and ability points.

Aside from that, there's just a whole bunch of general fixes. Most of them are for specific sections of the game, like one where an enemy would clip out of bounds meaning you couldn't kill it in A Kiss From Prospero, and multiple cases of the player character falling out of bounds after performing certain actions in particular places have been fixed. You can read the full list in this handy blog post.

In terms of what's next, before the end of the year patch 1.0.5 should be in your hands. This one will add in an FOV slider and motion blue toggle, and progress saving should be improved too. Then, in the winter update, there'll be some Christmas-themed cosmetics, and a custom difficulty mode will be added in. You won't be able to engage with this feature until after beating the game, however. It's been framed as a sort of new game plus type situation, just one where you can toggle specific things like your starting health or enemy awareness.

After that, in early 2026 a Valentine's update will arrive, with the game's Loose Cannon and The Flower and the Flame DLC coming throughout the year.

item.title: Five Years Of PS5: What The Numbers Say
item.content:encoded:
It has been five years since the PS5 was released, and here are the statistics it has accumulated during this time frame.

There is still a long way to go before we see the next generation of PlayStation consoles, the PS6, which is reportedly set to arrive sometime in 2027. As we await the next generation of PlayStation consoles, let‚Äôs take a look back at what the PlayStation 5 has accomplished since its release.

From 2020 to 2025, Here‚Äôs How the PS5 Has Grown Over the Past Five Years

Starting in 2020, the console was released with a high-speed SSD, immersive 3D Audio, and the DualSense wireless controller. It also debuted features like Share Screen, which allows players to watch friends‚Äô gameplay in real-time. The feature was used more than 1.6 billion times, totaling over 900 million hours of usage. Regarding accessibility, the console has expanded from 11 features at launch to 20 by 2025.

The following year, we saw innovation towards Share Play, with cross-gen share-play allowing PS5 players with PS Plus to virtually ‚Äòpass the controller‚Äô to friends using PS4. The feature has been used over 700 million times since launch. M.2 SSD storage expansion was introduced for players to grow their libraries further.

PS5 Game Captures received the ability to be shared through the PS App, resulting in 5.6 billion captures uploaded and over 1 billion voice chat sessions conducted through the app. The Midnight Black and Cosmic Red colour variations for the DualSense were also released in 2021.

2022 ‚Äì VRR, New PS Plus Tiers, and More Colors

Then the next year, PlayStation 5 received variable refresh rate or VRR, which helped enhance visual performance by minimizing visual artifacts for smoother, crisper gameplay. 96% of players with VRR-compatible monitors use this feature regularly. We also saw PlayStation Plus being turned into a three-tier service: Essential, Extra, and Premium/Deluxe. ‚ÄúThe total gameplay hours for Game Catalog and Classic Catalog have also increased ‚Äì cumulatively hitting 14 billion hours.‚Äù

Three more galaxy-inspired color variations were introduced for the DualSense in 2022: Nova Pink, Starlight Blue, and Galactic Purple.

2023 ‚Äì PlayStation VR2, PlayStation Portal, DualSense Edge, and More

2023 was the year of accessories; we first saw the release of the PSVR2, which featured eye tracking, headset feedback, haptic feedback, and adaptive triggers through the PSVR2 Sense Controllers. Discord voice chat has been introduced to the PS5, with more than 1 billion voice chat sessions taking place on the platform, averaging 105 minutes per session.

Then, the next device, PlayStation Portal, was introduced to redefine their remote play features, with the device accounting for over 50% of all PS5 Remote Play sessions. Innovation was also introduced to the controller space with the high-performance, ultra-customizable DualSense Edge and the Access Controller, designed to make games more accessible.

Cloud streaming for PS5 games also introduced new options for PlayStation Plus Premium members to stream supported PS5 digital games from the Game Catalog, Game Trials, and purchases made on the PS Store directly on their PS5 console. Lastly, a whole line of audio products was released with planar magnetic drivers, PlayStation Link technology, and lightning-fast, lossless audio connection.

2024 ‚Äì Community Game Help, Welcome Hub, and PS5 Pro

2024 was the year when Community Game Help was introduced, allowing players to share gameplay hint videos generated by opt-in contributors. The Welcome Hub was also added this year to bring a personalized PS5 home screen space with customizable widgets and backgrounds. Lastly, the mid-gen update, PS5 Pro, and the PlayStation 30th Anniversary Collection were also released that year.

2025 ‚Äì Here‚Äôs Where Everything Adds Up

2025 marks the 5th Anniversary of the PS5, and it has racked up some huge numbers in this time span. The console has sold over 84 million units globally, and if players ‚Äúlined up every PS5 ever sold, together they‚Äôd stretch over 28,600 kilometers‚Äù. Moreover, over 7,500 PS5 games have been published by more than 4,000 creators.

The top 3 multiplayer games on the PS5, based on playtime, are Fortnite, Grand Theft Auto V, and Call of Duty Modern Warfare II. The top 3 single-player games on PS5 are Assassin‚Äôs Creed Valhalla, God of War Ragnar√∂k, and Hogwarts Legacy. Combined, players have acquired over 40 billion Trophies and 110 million Platinum Trophies. Last but not least by any means, across the five years, PS5 players have logged a total of 100 billion hours of gameplay.

In other news, a PS5 & PC cross-buy option has been discovered and verified. Additionally, the Xbox port of Helldivers 2 helped increase sales of the PS5 and PC.
